document.docAuthor: Cavalcanti, Thaynã, Santos, George Garcia & Pinheiro, Ulisses
document.docTitle: Aulospongus trirhabdostylus Cavalcanti & Santos & Pinheiro 2014, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Two new species of Aulospongus Norman, 1878 with a key to the Atlantic species (Poecilosclerida; Demospongiae; Porifera)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Two new species of Aulospongus Norman, 1878 with a key to the Atlantic species (Poecilosclerida; Demospongiae; Porifera)

Universidade Federal de Pernambuco, Centro de Ciências Biológicas, Departamento de Zoologia, Av. Nelson Chaves, s / n Cidade Universitária CEP 50373 - 970, Recife, PE, Brazil

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality.
Brazil , Rio Grande do Norte State , Potiguar Basin
.

Type specimens.
Holotype .
UFPEPOR 1517, Bacia Potiguar ( 04º 44.8945' S ; 036º 25.4571' W ), Rio Grande do Norte State , Brazil , depth
108 m
, trawl, Bombona 39, col. Petrobras , (
23/05/2011
)
.
Paratypes :
UFPEPOR 1519, UFPEPOR 1520 and MNRJ 17487 (collected together with the holotype ); UFPEPOR 1521, Bacia Potiguar ( 04º 36.7198' S ; 036º 46.7554' W ), Rio Grande do Norte State , Brazil , depth
140 m
, trawl, Bombona 29, col. Petrobras , (
22/05/2011
)
.

Diagnosis.
Aulospongus trirhabdostylus
sp. nov.
is the only
Aulospongus
in Atlantic with three categories of rhabdostyles.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2.
Aulospongus trirhabdostylus
sp. nov.
(UFPEPOR 1517, holotype). A, preserved specimen showing oscules (arrows); B, surface details; C, detail of thick section showing brushes; D, thick section showing the ectosome and choanosome; E, detail of polyspicular tracts of echinating spicules. Scale bars: A = 1 cm; B = 500 µm; C–E = 300 µm.

FIGURE 3. Spicule composition of
Aulospongus trirhabdostylus
sp. nov.
(UFPEPOR 1517, holotype) in SEM. A, ectosomal auxiliary anisoxea; B, choanosomal principal rhabdostyles; C, echinating rhabdostyles; D, auxiliary rhabdostyles; E–H, details of respectively A–D. Scale bars: A = 40 µm; B = 20 µm; C = 10 µm; D = 20 µm; E–H = 2 µm; E’= 4 µm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
External morphology ( Fig. 2A–D ).
Massive–arborescent with digitiform projections, 6 x 5.5 x 5 cm (length x height x width) ( Fig. 2A ). Small oscules ( 0.8–1 mm ) are observed on the sides or on the tips of the projections ( Fig. 2A , arrows). Surface with bouquets of spicules irregularly distributed ( Fig. 2B ). Fibre-bundles are inter-connected by a thin layer of spongin ( Fig. 2B–C ). Consistency is elastic, not easily torn. Colour in life is unknown and brownish-purple in ethanol. However, the specimens were collected in the same drag as
Aiolochroia crassa ( Hyatt, 1875 )
and stored in the same container. It is possible that the
Aiolochroia crassa
pigments painted the
Aulospongus
specimens.

Spicules ( Fig. 3A–H ).
Ectosomal auxiliary anisoxeas (399– 473.3 –547 / 3– 4.0 – 6 µm ): long, thin, smooth, straight to slightly curved, with distinct tips (one sharply pointed and the other styloid) ( Fig. 3A, E , E’); Choanosomal principal rhabdostyles (rhabdostyles I) (127– 199.5 –287 / 7– 11.1 – 14 µm ): robust, slightly curved next to the basal region (rhabd), smooth base to a few spines (1–2), on the medium region to the tip composed of curved spines (hook-shaped) directed to the base, the spines near the tips are smaller and fewer than in the smaller rhabdostyles ( Fig. 3B, F ); Echinating rhabdostyles (rhabdostyles II) (90– 116.7 –155 / 3– 6.5 – 13 µm ): small, completely microspined, straight to slightly curved ( Fig. 3C, G ); Auxiliary rhabdostyles (rhabdostyles III) (171– 217.6 –277 / 2– 6.3 – 9 µm ): thin, with a slight curvature towards the end (slightly rhabdose base) and microspined (small granular spines) from the medium to the apical region ( Fig. 3D, H ).

Distribution ( Fig. 1 ).
Brazil : Northeastern Region: Rio Grande do Norte State : off Bacia Potiguar.
Etymology. The species name refers to the presence of three categories of rhabdostyles.

Remarks.
Aulospongus trirhabdostylus
sp. nov.
belongs the genus by the presence of three categories of rhabdostyles, plumose choanosomal skeleton with fibres ascending to the periphery. In comparison with the species from Atlantic,
Aulospongus trirhabdostylus
sp. nov.
differs from
A. monticularis
by its massive bulbousencrusting growth form, rhabdostyles I (completely smooth) and subectosomal extra-axial styles.
Aulospongus phakelloides
is a fan-shaped sponge, with two categories of echinating rhabdostyles and absence of anisoxeas.
Aulospongus samariensis
is club-shaped sponge, with one category of echinating rhabdostyles and the presence of styles.
Aulospongus spinosus
is a bulbous–erect sponge, with two categories of rhabdostyles (completely smooth), while
A. trirhabdostylus
sp. nov.
has massive-arborescent growth form, three categories of rhabdostyles (all with spines) and presence of anisoxeas (see Table 2, Fig. 3 ). The most similar species to
A . trirhabdostylus
sp. nov.
is
A. gardineri ( Dendy, 1922 )
from the Indian Ocean which also has three categories of rhabdostyles, but differs morphology of sponges, and in the morphology of rhabdostyles III (completely smooth in
A. gardineri
), presence of extra-axial styles, and spicules size (see Table 2). Finally,
A. gardineri
is known only from the Indian Ocean, making conspecificity highly improbable.
